Fig. 1 FTIR spectra (a) and XRD analysis (b) of PIL@SiO2 catalysts; (c) Pyridine-IR spectra of PIL@SiO2-18; (d) Full-spectrum of XPS for PIL@SiO2 catalysts. Fig 1 Fig. 2 XPS spectra of Si 2p (a), O 1s (b), N 1s (c), and C 1s (d) of PIL@SiO2 samples. Fig 2 Fig. 3 SEM images of (a) PIL@SiO2-14, (b) PIL@SiO2-16, (c) PIL@SiO2-18. Fig 3 Fig. 4 TEM (a) and TEM-HAADF (b) image of a PIL@SiO2-18 nanosphere; EDS mapping of (d) C, (e) N, (f) O, (g) Si, and (h) Br in PIL@SiO2-18 (c) sample. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Effects of length of alkyl chain on the yield of 5-HMF prepared from (a)fructose, (b)glucose. (Conditions: (a) 66.7 mM fructose, 5 mL of reaction solution (MIBK-Sat.NaCl=70: 30 (v/v)), 190 °C, 1 h; (b) 66.7 mM glucose, 5 mL of reaction solution (MIBK-Sat.NaCl=70: 30 (v/v)), 200 °C, 2 h) Fig 5 Fig. 6 Effects of reaction temperature on the yield of 5-HMF prepared from fructose (a) and glucose (b). (Conditions: (a) 66.7 mM fructose, 20 mg PIL@SiO2-18, 5 mL of reaction solution (MIBK-Sat.NaCl=70: 30 (v/v)); (b) 66.7 mM glucose, 20 mg PIL@SiO2-18, 5 mL of reaction solution (MIBK-Sat.NaCl=70: 30 (v/v))). Fig 6 Fig. 7 Effects of dosage of PIL@SiO2-18 on the yield of 5-HMF prepared from fructose (a) and glucose (b). (Conditions: (a) 66.7 mM fructose, 5 mL of reaction solution (MIBK-Sat.NaCl=70: 30 (v/v)), 190 °C, 1 h; (b) 66.7 mM glucose, 5 mL of reaction solution (MIBK-Sat.NaCl=70: 30 (v/v)), 200 °C, 2 h) Fig 7 Fig. 8 Effects of concentration of substrate on the yield of 5-HMF prepared from fructose (a) and glucose (b). (Conditions: (a) 66.7 mM fructose, 5 mL of reaction solution (MIBK-Sat.NaCl=70: 30 (v/v)), 190 °C, 1 h; (b) 66.7 mM glucose, 5 mL of reaction solution (MIBK-Sat.NaCl=70: 30 (v/v)), 200 °C, 2 h) Fig 8 Fig. 9 Reusability of PIL@SiO2-18 catalyst. Scheme 2 Table 1 The effect of different proportions of MIBK and Sat.NaCl on 5-HMF yield Table 1 Entry Volume of solvent (mL) Yield (%) MIBK Sat.NaCl Organic phase Inorganic phase Total 1 0 5 0 14.33 14.33 2 1.5 3..5 32.94 18.58 51.52 3 2.5 2.5 58.01 12.22 70.23 4 3.5 1.5 65.87 6.93 72.80 5 4 1 63.51 4.74 68.25 6 5 0 3.29 0 3.29 (Conditions: 66.7 mM glucose, 5 mL of reaction solution (MIBK-Sat.NaCl), 200 °C, 2 h) Poly (ionic liquid)s-silica spheres as effective core-shell catalysts for the conversion of glucose and fructose into 5-hydroxymethylfurfural Niuniu Zhu Conceptualization Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Manyu Zhang Data curation Validation Congcong Zhao Data curation Validation Guo Qiu Conceptualization Methodology Resources Writing – review & editing ⁎ Hongyu Tian Supervision Resources Beijing Key Laboratory of Flavor Chemistry, Beijing Technology and Business University, Beijing 100048, China Beijing Key Laboratory of Flavor Chemistry Beijing Technology and Business University Beijing 100048 China Beijing Key Laboratory of Flavor Chemistry, Beijing Technology and Business University, Beijing 100048, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF), as a significant, bio-derived platform chemical molecule, has been under extensive research due to its wide application in petrochemical industry. In this work, three kinds of poly (ionic liquid)s-silica spheres (PIL@SiO2) with various lengths of alkyl chains as effective core-shell catalysts were prepared by the polymerization and coating methods, and were used to prepare 5-HMF from glucose and fructose with optimal results. When the alkyl carbon number of PIL monomer was 18, PIL@SiO2-18 displayed good catalytic activity in 5-HMF production, resulting in the highest yields of 77.36% and 72.8% from glucose and fructose in methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK)/ saturated solution of sodium chloride (Sat.NaCl) biphasic solvent. A possible reaction mechanism was proposed that the core-shell synergistic catalysis effectively promoted the preparation of 5-HMF from monosaccharide, in which Lewis acidic polycationic centers contributed to driving the isomerization process. The promising approach provides an efficient strategy for silica-based core-shell synergistic catalysts in the synthesis of 5-HMF from carbohydrates. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural Glucose Fructose Core-shell Poly (ionic liquid)s-Silica Spheres Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction With the gradual reduction of fossil energy and the degradation of natural environment, studying the development and utilization of biomass energy has become one of the main trends of renewable energy due to the characteristics of low-cost and pollution-free [1–3]. Biomass can serve as a kind of potential and alternative energy sources, which have twice as much energy storage as the total energy consumption in the world [4,5]. Carbohydrates, possessing relatively stable biochemical properties, are regarded as one of the most important raw materials for green organic chemistry. In recent years, the synthesis of platform compounds from the chemical conversion of carbohydrates feedstocks have been investigated worldwide [6], and furan-based chemicals can be obtained through the hydrolysis and dehydration of sugars [7]. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) can be considered to be one of the most significant platform chemicals with great potential and wide application, and the special chemical structure of 5-HMF, including furan ring, hydroxyl group and aldehyde group, which could be converted to generate a wide variety of secondary chemicals. In this case, 5-HMF has received much focus as a versatile platform material applied in the field of functional polyester, pharmaceutical intermediates and renewable polymeric materials [8–11]. With the consideration of the high efficiency in 5-HMF synthesis, hexoses have been regarded as the preferred substrate for converting carbohydrates into value-added chemicals. Among hexoses, fructose could be more prone to dehydration with the highest reactivity and 5-HMF selectivity, due to its furan structure easily converted to the target product 5-HMF [12,13]. Relatively speaking, there are certain difficulties for glucose converting to 5-HMF, and the initial ring-opening process become tough as a result of its stable pyran ring structure [12,14]. Despite all this, glucose is considered as one of the most promising substrate for 5-HMF production because of its wide materials supply and low cost [15]. Therefore, much effort has been devoted to transforming fructose and glucose into 5-HMF. It is well known that the synergistic effect of Brønsted acid and Lewis acid can effectively promote the dehydration of monosaccharide to produce 5-HMF, while most of the now available catalysts rely on the supported metal to provide Lewis acid. For example, Chen et al. found the supported metal Cr(III) on PCP(Cr)-SO3H catalyst as Lewis acid sites gave a 80.7% 5-HMF yield from glucose in 180 °C for 4 h [16]. A 62% glucose conversion and 62.1% 5-HMF selectivity were reported with a [Sn, Al]-Beta catalyst, the catalytic effect of which is much higher than H-Al-Beta [17]. Based on the research of Polshettiwar et al [18], Al-KCC-1 catalyst was prepared through metal aluminum loading on KCC-1, and 5-HMF yields of 92.9% and 39% were successfully obtained with fructose and glucose as substrate, respectively [19]. However, there are still plenty of shortcomings in the catalytic reaction with metal supported catalysts, such as eco-friendly defects, toxicity in soil, and high cost, which is not conducive to the large-scale application. Ionic liquids can not only be used as solvent but also catalyst in organic reactions due to wide liquid temperature range, good stability, non-volatility, friendly-environment, non-flammability non-toxicity and strong conductivity [20–22]. Therefore, it has also been widely concerned and gradually used for the hydrolysis of carbohydrates to prepare 5-HMF in recent years. Qi et al. reported that using [BMIM][Cl] as solvent can greatly reduce the reaction temperature required for converting fructose to 5-HMF [23]. Hou et al. used ionic liquid [EMIM][Br] as solvent and SnPO as catalyst to achieve the realization of the synergistic catalytic effect and a high yield of 58.3% of 5-HMF from glucose [24]. Moreover, Qu et al. reported that [AEMIM]BF4 showed a high catalytic activity and selectivity for the hydrolysis of sucrose [25]. Ionic liquid combined with heterogeneous support can provide a new model for designing active catalyst, and it has been widely concerned by researchers and some achievements have been made. Saxena et al. proposed a ionic liquid-encapsulated zeolite catalysts in 2017, and they found that the yield and selectivity were higher with the composite catalyst as compared to blank control groups involving zeolite support counterpart or ILs [26]. Therefore, the composite materials integrating ILs with heterogeneous catalyst can provide new approach to design an efficient system for organic synthesis. Based on all of above, three kinds of poly (ionic liquid)s-silica spheres (PIL@SiO2) with various lengths of alkyl chains as novel and effective spherical core-shell catalysts were prepared and used for 5-HMF synthesis from monosaccharide in MIBK-Sat.NaCl biphasic solvent. Considering the space effect and interface adhesion [27], three kinds of alkyl chains with different carbon chain length (tetradecyl, hexadecyl and octadecyl) were first introduced into vinyl imidazole to enable the substrate glucose to be more easily adsorbed on the polycationic imidazole ring. Through the protection of the silica shell, poly (ionic liquid)s with high catalytic activity can maintain good stability at higher temperature. Correspondingly, poly (ionic liquid)s with long alkyl chains in the core have helped support for the acidic silica shell in order to maintain the stability. The silica hydroxyl of the shell and the polycationic species in the core could provide Brønsted and Lewis acid sites required for the reaction, respectively [28]. The core-shell synergistic catalysis in the preparation of 5-HMF from monosaccharide can be realized. The optimal reaction conditions and the reaction mechanism of 5-HMF synthesis in PIL@SiO2 catalytic system were further discussed. These findings offer a feasibility of further designing a novel and effective core-shell catalytic system for 5-HMF synthesis. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials D-glucose (99%), D-fructose (99%), 4-methyl-2-pentanone (≥99.5%), methanol (≥99.9%), ethyl ether (AR), ethanol (99.5%), sodium chloride (≥99.5%), ammonium hydroxide solution (AR, 25%-28%), 2, 2’-azobis (2-methyl-N-(2-hydroxyethyl)propionamide) (98%) and 1-vinylimidazole (99%) were gained from HWRK Chem co., Ltd (Beijing, China). Cetyltrime-thylammonium bromide (CTAB, 99%), 1-bromooctadecane (99%), tetraethoxysilane (99%) and 1,4-dibromobutane (99%) were acquired from Damas-beta (Shanghai, China), and 1-bromotetradecane (97%) and 1-bromohexadecane (97%) were supplied by 9 Ding Chemistry Technology Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). Each chemical was used as received. 2.2 Catalysts preparation Synthesis of 3-n-alkyl-1-vinylimidzaolium bromide (ILM-CnBr, n=14, 16, 18): Initially, 0.1 mol of n-alkyl bromide, 0.1 mol of 1-vinyl imidazole and 30 mL of methanol were added into a 100 mL round bottom flask with 15 h of vigorous stirring at 60 °C. After quenching, the reaction mixture was dropped into 1 L of anhydrous ether and a large amount of white sedimentation was generated. Finally, filter out the white sedimentation and dry it to constant weight at 40 °C. Synthesis of 1, 4-butanediyl-3, 3′-bis-l-vinylimidazoliurn dibromide (BVDB): 0.1 mol of 1,4-dibromobutane, 0.2 mol of 1-vinyl imidazole and 30 mL of methanol were added into a 100 mL round bottom flask with 15 h of vigorous stirring at 60 °C. After quenching, the reaction mixture was dropped into 1 L of anhydrous ether and a large amount of white sedimentation was generated. Finally, filter out the white sedimentation and dry it to constant weight at 40 °C. Synthesis of poly (ionic liquid)s (PIL) nanospheres: Firstly, a certain amount of ILM-CnBr monomer, initiator, BVDB crosslinking agent, and water were charged into a 250 mL reactor. Then, the mixture was vacuumized by a water pump and continuously stirred in the oil bath with the constant temperature of 70 °C for 24 h, while nitrogen was continuously injected. Finally, the formed dispersion was quenched to room temperature. The sample were marked as PIL-14, PIL-16 and PIL-18. Synthesis of PIL@SiO2 spheres: Firstly, 15 mL of PIL dispersion was added to a mixture solvent of H2O and ethanol, containing 1.5 g of CTAB and NH3•H2O (0.5 mL, 28 wt%). Then, the mixture was located in an oil bath at 38 °C after 15 min of ultrasonic treatment. Furthermore, 0.2 mL of tetraethyl orthosilicate was measured into the reactor with 24 h of vigorous stirring at 38 °C. Through centrifugation separation, the white precipitate was washed three times with ethanol, prior to drying at 80 °C overnight. Based on the carbon chain length of alkyl group, the sample were marked as PIL@SiO2-14, PIL@SiO2-16 and PIL@SiO2-18. The synthesis route for each step was shown in Fig. S1. In addition, the synthetic method of metal-loaded PIL@SiO2 spheres was described in Supporting information. 2.3 Catalysts characterization Fourier transform infrared (FTIR, iS 10, Nicolet) spectroscope with the wave number range from 400 to 4000 cm−1 was used to characterize the structure and chemical bonding state of PIL@SiO2 catalysts. X-ray diffractometer (XRD, smartlab, Japan) was used to analyze the crystallinity of PIL@SiO2 and the diffraction pattern was collected in the 2θ range of 5-90° with a copper target and the scanning speed of 5 °/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI5000 Versaprobe III, Japan) was used to analyze the surface elements and chemical states. The surface acidic properties (Brønsted/ Lewis acidic sites) were determined by pyridine infrared spectroscopy (Pyridine-IR) with tensor 27 spectrometer. The morphology of PIL@SiO2 was characterized by transmission electron microscope (TEM, Fei talosf200x, US) and scanning electron microscope (SEM, JSM-7800F, Japan). The specific surface area and porosity analyzer (BET, Micromeritics ASAP 2460, US) were used to observe the specific surface area and pore size of PIL@SiO2. Nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometer (NMR, Bruker 300, German) was used for qualitative analysis of PIL monomers. The temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD, Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920, US) was used to determine the acid strength and total acid content of PIL@SiO2-18. 2.4 General procedure for converting monosaccharides to 5-HMF In a typical procedure, a certain amount of monosaccharide and PIL@SiO2 were added into a biphasic solvent system, and conduct the dehydration reaction at 190 °C for 1 h in the high-pressure reaction tube with the stirring speed of 30 rpm. After the reaction, the mixture was quenched to room temperature. Furthermore, MIBK phase and Sat.NaCl phase were filtered through 0.45-micron filter membrane and put into 5 mL centrifuge tube, respectively. Finally, methanol and ultrapure water were used to dilute MIBK phase and Sat.NaCl phase respectively. The concentration of 5-HMF was quantified by waters 2695 HPLC, equipped with an UV detector and a C18 column. 10% acetonitrile and 90% ultrapure water were utilized as the mobile phase at a flow rate of 1 mL/min. The residual monosaccharide was detected by HPLC using a HPX-87H column and a RI detector, and 5 mM sulfuric acid was selected as the mobile phase at a flow rate of 0.6 mL min−1. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization of PIL@SiO2 catalysts As shown in Fig. 1 a, the chemical structure of PIL@SiO2-14, PIL@SiO2-16 and PIL@SiO2-18 was verified by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, and there were no significant differences observed in FTIR spectra of PIL@SiO2 with different length of alkyl chain. Obviously, a band at approximately 3422 cm−1 was attributed to O-H asymmetric stretching vibration of PIL@SiO2 samples [29]. The sharp bands at 2925 and 2854 cm−1 were assigned to C-H vibration of -CH3 and -CH2, respectively [30]. A band at about 1550 cm−1 was associated to the vibration of C=N in the imidazole ring, while the band at 1467 cm−1 was related to C=C vibration [31,32]. The appearance of these above functional groups confirmed that the framework structure of poly (ionic liquid)s meets the requirements for design. The characteristic band at 1080 cm−1 was associated to the asymmetric stretching vibration of Si-O-Si and a band at 955 cm−1 corresponded to the bending vibration of Si-OH, while the bands at 800 cm−1 and 463 cm−1 were related to the symmetric stretching vibration of Si-O [33]. These characteristic bands were consistent with the framework of SiO2, indicating the generation of SiO2 shell in synthetic process. The powder XRD analysis was performed over the 2θ range of 5°-90°. As shown in Fig. 1b, there was a large peak appeared at 21.4°, indicating the formation of an amorphous phase in PIL@SiO2 samples [34]. The result of nitrogen isothermal adsorption-desorption (Table S1) indicated that the specific surface area and pore size of PIL@SiO2-18 were the largest among three catalysts. Pyridine adsorption infrared spectra was used to determine the types of acid sites. As shown in Fig. 1c, there were some characteristic absorption bands observed at the wave number of about 1440, 1490 and 1554 cm−1 in pyridine-IR spectra of PIL@SiO2-18. The band at 1440 cm−1 corresponded to Lewis acid sites, which were provided by some uncoordinated polyimidazole cations in the PIL core. The band centered at 1554 cm−1 was in accordance with Brønsted acid sites, owing to pyridine molecules protonated at the Si-OH group in the surface of SiO2 shell. Furthermore, a band at 1490 cm−1 was related to the interaction of pyridine molecules with both above acid sites [35,36]. These results demonstrated that both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were simultaneously appeared in PIL@SiO2-18 catalysts. NH3-TPD spectra of PIL@SiO2-18 was shown in Fig. S2. It is obvious that three characteristic absorption bands were involved in the spectrum, in which the absorption peak in the range of 100-300 °C was consistent with the weak acid sites. Combined with NH3-TPD and pyridine infrared results (Table S2), the density of Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites were also quantified, indicating that PIL@SiO2-18 possessed Lewis and Brønsted acidity. The 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectrum of PIL monomers (Fig. S3, Fig. S4, Fig. S5) and crosslinking agents (Fig. S6) are as follows. The determination of these groups demonstrates that the structure of PIL completely conforms to the design. In order to explore the elemental chemical states of Si, O, N and C in three PIL@SiO2 samples, XPS spectra are reported in Fig. 1d and Fig. 2 . Both the Si 2p spectra (Fig. 2a) and O 1s spectra (Fig. 2b) involves only one peak, which were centered at 103.3 eV and 532.5 eV [37–39], respectively; these peaks are characteristic of silica shell. In addition, the curves on the N 1s spectra (Fig. 2c) were fitted into three peaks with binding energies of 399.19 eV, 401.3 eV and 402.5 eV, corresponding to C=N, C-N and N+ of imidazole, respectively [40–42]. Similarly, Fig. 2d shows the C1s spectra of PIL@SiO2, in which a peak located at 284.8 eV assigned to C-C and C=C, while the other peak at 286.4 eV coincided with C-N [43]. SEM images of PIL@SiO2 samples are presented in Fig. 3 . As can be seen, there were some aggregation structure of spherical particles with the average sizes of about 200∼300 nm formed in three kinds of PIL@SiO2 samples, indicating that the generation of symmetrically spherical silica structures. As can be seen in Fig. 4 , TEM images show that the morphology of PIL@SiO2-18 possessed obvious core-shell structure, in which the outer shell layer was spherical silica polymer with a size of about 200 nm, and the inner core layer was poly (ionic liquid)s chain with a size of approximately 150 nm. Furthermore, it is clear that the distribution of C, N, O, Si and Br elements in PIL@SiO2-18 samples could be respectively detected by STEM-EDS mappings, confirming the simultaneous existence of the above elements on the core-shell catalysts. 3.2 Effect of alkyl chain length on synthesis of 5-HMF from glucose and fructose Fig. 5 sums up the performance of PIL@SiO2 with different kernel alkyl chain length on 5-HMF synthesis in biphasic solvent. Above 50% yields of 5-HMF were attained using PIL@SiO2 as a catalyst, revealing that PIL@SiO2 catalytic system exhibited good promotion on the conversion of glucose and fructose, which was due to the catalysis of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, stemming from polycationic centers and external surface Si-OH group, respectively. In this case, there were synchronous increasing trends on 5-HMF yields from fructose and glucose with increasing the number of carbon atoms on the core alkyl chain of PIL@SiO2 catalyst in the range of 14-18, conclusively demonstrating that the alkyl chain of poly (ionic liquid)s could promote the formation of 5-HMF. When the alkyl chain of polycationic centers was octadecane, 5-HMF yields obtained from the conversion of glucose and fructose reached the maximum, which were 72.8% and 77.36%, respectively. In other words, the number of carbon atoms on the alkyl chain was 18 in PIL@SiO2 catalyst, tending to form more target products on account of stronger steric effect of longer alkyl chain in the kernel space, which could create a favorable environment for the isomerization and the accommodation of more substrates [27]. In addition, the longer alkyl chain possessed stronger interfacial bonding, which can provide better stability as a support to reinforce the structure of the silica shell in PIL@SiO2 catalyst [44]. The relatively large specific surface area and pore size of PIL@SiO2-18 promote the interfacial adsorption between substrate and catalyst, which may also be one of the reasons for its better catalytic performance. Therefore, the number of carbon atoms is 18 as the optimal alkyl chain of PIL@SiO2 in the catalytic transformation of glucose and fructose under these reaction conditions, and the alkyl chain length of polycationic center has a great impact on the yield of 5-HMF. A series of controlled experiments were conducted to explore the catalytic effect of PIL-18 and SiO2 on the synthesis of 5-HMF from glucose, as shown in Table S3. It was evident that without the addition of any catalyst, the yields of 5-HMF and fructose were extremely low, with less than 20% of glucose being converted. With silicon-free PIL-18 used as a catalyst, the conversion of glucose into fructose was high, but less than 20% in the yield of 5-HMF was obtained. This is because weak Lewis acid sites provided by the cationic imidazole ring on PIL-18 promoted the isomerization process of glucose to fructose, but the absence of Si-OH on the silicon-free PIL-18 prevented the subsequent dehydration of fructose, which further confirmed that Brønsted acid sites required for the dehydration stemmed from external surface Si-OH groups. With SiO2 as a catalyst, the silyl hydroxyl group could promote the conversion of a small amount of glucose; however, the yield of 5-HMF was low due to the absence of Lewis acid sites leading to the inability of the isomerization step. The above results demonstrated the necessity of preparing composite core-shell PIL@SiO2 catalysts. When the alkyl carbon number of PIL monomer was 12, the catalytic performance of PIL@SiO2-12 was further investigated, and the result was showed in Table S3 (entry5). It is obvious that the catalytic activity of PIL@SiO2-12 was much lower than that of PIL@SiO2-18. When the alkyl chain length was further shortened with the alkyl carbon number of 8, PIL@SiO2-8 could not be synthesized, due to the inability of PIL to recrystallize during the first step of synthesis. Table S4 summarizes the effects of other reported catalysts in the preparation of 5-HMF from glucose, further demonstrating the excellent catalytic performance of PIL@SiO2-18 catalysts. In addition, there was observed that the different metals loaded on PIL@SiO2 also have influence on the catalytic activity, as shown in Table S5. It is obvious that PIL@SiO2 loaded with niobium and tin possessed preferable performance relative to other metals, which could be attributed to Lewis acidity of niobium and tin facilitating the isomerization process. With Fe as loading metal, the effect of alkyl chain length of polycationic center on synthesis of 5-HMF was further explored (Fig. S7), and the results show that PIL@SiO2 bonded with octadecyl had better catalytic activity, indicating stronger interfacial bonding would offer steric stability as a kernel support. In a word, the alkyl chain length of polycationic center played a significant role in 5-HMF synthesis, and metal-free PIL@SiO2 showed an excellent catalytic activation and stability. 3.3 Effect of reaction temperature on synthesis of 5-HMF from fructose and glucose Fig. 6 a shows the significant effect of PIL@SiO2-18 system on the catalytic activity for 5-HMF synthesis from fructose at different temperatures. Obviously, relatively low temperature resulted in a certain 5-HMF yield due to higher catalytic activity of PIL@SiO2 samples. As raising the reaction temperature, the 5-HMF yield increased significantly at the initial stage of the reaction. However, it doesn't necessarily mean that the higher the temperature, the higher the ultimate yield of 5-HMF. It is obvious that the maximum 5-HMF yield of 77.36% was gained at 190 °C in 60 min. The highest 5-HMF yield decreased once the temperature was continuously increased to 200 °C, possibly due to high temperature resulting in the occurrence of some side reactions such as the carbonization of sugar and the polymerization of products and substrates. In this case, the polymerization by-product covering the surface of PIL@SiO2-18 could weaken the catalytic activity. Therefore, in order to avoid the influence of side reactions and improve the catalytic activity of PIL@SiO2-18, the optimum temperature and reaction time for preparing 5-HMF from fructose was 190 °C for 1 h. Similarly, the different reaction temperature affected greatly the conversion of glucose in PIL@SiO2-18-catalytic system. As exposed in Fig. 6b, the initial rate of the reaction was comparatively slow with the generation of only a small amount of 5-HMF in the temperature range of 170 °C–180 °C. The increase of temperature could remarkably improve the performance of PIL@SiO2-18 system in the early stage of reaction, and the highest 5-HMF yield was 72.8% at 200 °C for 2 h. In this case, only less than 5% formic acid (FA) and levulinic acid (LA) were detected (Fig. S8), indicating that the hydration side reaction was effectively suppressed. When raising the temperature above 200 °C, the time required for reaching the highest yield could be shorten; However, the 5-HMF yield decreased rapidly with the extension of reaction time due to the side reactions. The gradual formation of some black humins could be observed when the temperature exceeded 200 °C. Thus, choosing an appropriate reaction temperature was essential for the preparation of 5-HMF from monosaccharides. 3.4 Effects of dosage of PIL@SiO2-18 on 5-HMF synthesis from fructose and glucose The effects of dosage of PIL@SiO2-18 on the preparation of 5-HMF from monosaccharides were experimented, as shown in Fig. 7 . When the dosage of PIL@SiO2-18 was in the range from 10 mg to 20 mg, the yields of 5-HMF showed increasing tendency with fructose and glucose as substrates. The highest 5-HMF yields were achieved to 77.36% and 72.8% from fructose and glucose, respectively. This was because the isomerization of glucose and dehydration of fructose can be effectively promoted with the acidic active sites provided by PIL@SiO2-18. Relatively, as the dosage was continuously increased to 50 mg, there was a decline in the yield of 5-HMF with a decrease of 11.12% from fructose and a larger drop of 18.56% from glucose. This might be due to too much content of PIL@SiO2-18 catalysts with an appearance of polymerization preventing the interaction between PIL@SiO2-18 and substrate molecules, further resulting in less substantial loss of 5-HMF yield. Therefore, 20 mg of PIL@SiO2-18 was selected as the optimum dosage of catalyst. 3.5 Effects of concentration of fructose and glucose on synthesis of 5-HMF To study the influence of substrate concentration on 5-HMF yield, a sequence of different concentrations of fructose and glucose were utilized for the dehydration reaction. As illustrated in Fig. 8 , the maximum 5-HMF yield were respectively 72.8% and 77.36% when the concentration of glucose and fructose was 66.7 mM. The 5-HMF yield decreased regardless of whether the concentration was lower or higher than 66.7 mM, indicating that too high or too low concentration of substrate was not conducive to PIL@SiO2-18-catalytic system. The reason for these results was that the probability of acidic sites on the surface of PIL@SiO2-18 contacting with sugar molecules was greatly increased in the low-concentration substrate reaction system, so as to better helping facilitate monosaccharide dehydration. In contrast, 5-HMF yield gained from fructose and glucose decreased with the increasing substrate concentration, this was mainly ascribed to that overconcentration of substrate could also lead to excessive collision between 5-HMF and sugar molecules and the occurrence of cross-linking polymerization, which was unfavorable to the reaction. 3.6 The effect of different proportions of MIBK and Sat.NaCl on 5-HMF yield The effect of different proportions of organic phase (MIBK) and inorganic phase (Sat.NaCl) on the yield of 5-HMF were studied using glucose as the substrate (Table 1 ). Obviously, the performance of PIL@SiO2-18 in the biphasic solvents was superior to the single-phase MIBK and Sat.NaCl solvents. This was because reactants and products were prone to condensation reactions in a single-phase solvent, while the biphasic solvents could effectively avoid the occurrence of side reactions. Secondly, it can be seen that in the biphasic solvents, the volume proportion of organic to inorganic phases was not linearly correlated with the yield of 5-HMF. When the volume proportion of MIBK to Sat.NaCl was 1, the yield of 5-HMF in the MIBK phase was higher than that in the Sat.NaCl phase, indicating that organic solvents possessed a better ability to accommodate 5-HMF molecules than inorganic solvents. In addition, it was evident that the optimal volume proportion of MIBK-Sat.NaCl solvent was 3.5: 1.5, and the yield of 5-HMF was as high as 72.8%. 3.7 Catalyst recyclability PIL@SiO2-18 was recycled and reused to evaluate its recyclability, and the result was shown in Fig. 9 . After the reaction, PIL@SiO2-18 catalyst was filtered and collected, then washed with deionized water for three times, and the collected sample was dried at 40 °C for 24 h. After four cycles of experiments, fructose conversion and 5-HMF yield were 91.8% and 75.93%, respectively, which were slightly lower than those in the initial reaction. This might be due to the small amount of by-product on the active site of PIL@SiO2-18, or the partial coverage of main product on the active site. Hence, PIL@SiO2-18 can be effectively separated and recycled in 5-HMF synthesis. 3.8 Mechanism of glucose and fructose conversion to 5-HMF Combined with the experimental results, the possible reaction mechanism of preparing 5-HMF from monosaccharide with PIL@SiO2 as catalyst has been speculated. It is obvious that the conversion reaction involves two major steps through the core-shell synergistic catalysis: (1) glucose isomerization to fructose and (2) fructose dehydration to 5-HMF (Fig. S9) [45]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were utilized for the optimization of the structure of PIL@SiO2, fructose and glucose molecules [46]. Reasonable models of PIL@SiO2 polycationic monomer, shell silica fragment, fructose and glucose were constructed in Materials Studio 7.0, and were calculated for optimizing to an appropriate cluster with the LYP correlation function (B3LYP) in Gaussian 16 [47]. The geometry optimization for C, Si, H, O and N atoms was conducted through the basis set of 6-31G (d). Electrostatic potential calculation in Glucose-PIL (1C) indicates that the presence of adsorption between glucose molecule and polycationic imidazole species acting as Lewis acid centers (Fig. 10 a). When polycationic monomer was bonded with octadecyl, it can be seen that the existence of the attraction with stronger interfacial bonding offering steric stability (Fig. 10b). SiO2 shell can promote the dehydration of fructose molecule to a certain extent, this is mainly ascribed to that silicon hydroxyl groups on the surface has strong adsorption with fructose molecule through stronger hydrogen bonding and weaker van der Waals forces (Fig. 10c and d). There is a relative balance in the surface electrostatic potential of the optimized adsorption sites between PIL@SiO2 and polyhydroxy carbohydrate molecule, thus promoting the adsorption of substrate molecules and the dehydration of fructose molecule. Indeed, the first step can be achieved through Lewis acid catalyzed intramolecular hydrogen transfer (Scheme 1 ) [48]. Initially, the anion-cation coordination effect on the surface of PIL polymer cation chain inside PIL@SiO2 catalyst plays a central role in the isomerization process. A portion of polyimidazole cation coordinate with hydroxyl ion in the solution, while other uncoordinated polycation centers could provide weak Lewis acid sites [28]. The active hydrogen on the imidazole ring with weak Lewis acidity first coordinates with the electronegative O1 on glucose, leading to a proton from O1H on glucose molecule transferring to OH− adsorbed on the imidazole ring (1-2-3-4). Next, the imidazole ring H proton obtained from the O1 site transfers to the pyranose O5 site, leading to the O5 protonation and further ring opening, and forming the aldehyde group at the O1 site (4-5-6). After that, the hydrogen proton at the O2 site is transferred to the OH− anion adsorbed on the imidazole ring and the active hydrogen on the imidazole ring changes from coordination with O1 to coordination with O2, resulting in the deprotonation of O2H and the regeneration of hydroxyl groups on the imidazole ring (6-7-8). The next molecular endoplasm transfer from C2 to C1 involves the generation of a five member chelate structure, leading to the transformation from the aldehyde O1 to the carbonyl O2 and the aldose ketose isomerization (8-9-10), which is combine with the formation of the open chain form of O1 deprotonated fructose bound to the active hydrogen site on the imidazole ring. Subsequently, the transmission of hydrogen protons from the O5 site to the O2 site promoted the closed-loop process and produced O1 deprotonated cyclic fructose (10-11-12). The proton transfer from OH on the imidazole ring to the terminal O1 site leads to the formation of the isomerized product furan fructose, and restored the original structure of the internal PIL (12-13-14), completing the catalytic cycle of glucose isomerization to fructose. From an experimental perspective, the presence of fructose can be detected at the initial stage of the reaction, when PIL@SiO2-18 was used as a catalyst (Fig. S10). These results are a further proof that the step of glucose isomerization to fructose is feasible. As the second step (Scheme 2 ), the three-step dehydration of fructose to 5-HMF is mainly achieved due to the catalysis of Brønsted acid [49]. In the synthesis of PIL@SiO2, terminal hydroxyl groups were formed at the edge of the outer SiO2 from some adsorbed water molecules, and the Brønsted acidic Si-OH attacks the C2-OH bond of fructose to form the first water molecule under the action of hydrogen bond, which generates aldehyde groups on the branch chain (1-2-3-4). Eventually, C3-OH bond and C4-OH bond are also striked by hydrogen proton of Si-OH, leading to the formation of furan ring and two water molecules, along with the acquisition of 5-HMF and the restoration of the outer layer structure of SiO2 (4-5-6). 4 Conclusions Three kinds of novel poly (ionic liquid)s-silica spherical core-shell catalysts with good catalytic effect were successfully prepared in the conversion of glucose and fructose. The highest 5-HMF yield of 72.8% was obtained in MIBK-Sat.NaCl biphasic solvent with 66.7 mM of glucose and 20 mg of PIL@SiO2-18 at 200 °C for 2 h. With the excellent catalytic performance of PIL@SiO2-18, 5-HMF yield from fructose could reach 77.36% at 190 °C for 1 h. In addition, the reaction mechanism for glucose converting to 5-HMF under the core-shell synergetic catalysis of PIL@SiO2 was proposed, in which Lewis acidic facilitated the isomerization of glucose with the silicon hydroxyl groups acting as Brønsted acid sites necessary for the dehydration process. The alkyl chains of polycationic center exerted a steric effect and strong support to ensure the catalytic adsorption and stability of PIL@SiO2. This study offers a new and promising way to produce 5-HMF from carbohydrates through the core-shell synergetic catalysis. coredata.dc:description: 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF), as a significant, bio-derived platform chemical molecule, has been under extensive research due to its wide application in petrochemical industry. In this work, three kinds of poly (ionic liquid)s-silica spheres (PIL@SiO2) with various lengths of alkyl chains as effective core-shell catalysts were prepared by the polymerization and coating methods, and were used to prepare 5-HMF from glucose and fructose with optimal results. When the alkyl carbon number of PIL monomer was 18, PIL@SiO2-18 displayed good catalytic activity in 5-HMF production, resulting in the highest yields of 77.36% and 72.8% from glucose and fructose in methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK)/ saturated solution of sodium chloride (Sat.NaCl) biphasic solvent. A possible reaction mechanism was proposed that the core-shell synergistic catalysis effectively promoted the preparation of 5-HMF from monosaccharide, in which Lewis acidic polycationic centers contributed to driving the isomerization process. The promising approach provides an efficient strategy for silica-based core-shell synergistic catalysts in the synthesis of 5-HMF from carbohydrates.
coredata.dc:title: Poly (ionic liquid)s-silica spheres as effective core-shell catalysts for the conversion of glucose and fructose into 5-hydroxymethylfurfural
